index.html
Make a map Let’s Git started License

Make a map Randy Swaty 2024-01-03 Let’s Git started Still from Heaven King video Happy Git provides opinionated instructions on how to: Install Git and get it working smoothly with GitHub, in the shell and in the RStudio IDE. Develop a few key workflows that cover your most common tasks. Integrate Git and GitHub into your daily work with R and R Markdown. The target reader is someone who uses R for data analysis or who works on R packages, although some of the content may be useful to those working in adjacent areas. The first two parts, Installation and Connect Git, GitHub, RStudio, provide a “batteries included” quick start to verify your setup. In Early GitHub Wins, we rack up some early success with the basic workflows that are necessary to get your work onto GitHub. We also show the special synergy between R/R Markdown/RStudio and GitHub, which provides a powerful demonstration of why all this setup is worthwhile. The use of Git/GitHub in data science has a slightly different vibe from that of pure software development, due to differences in the user’s context and objective. Happy Git aims to complement existing, general Git resources by highlighting the most rewarding usage patterns for data science. This perspective on the Git landscape is presented in Basic Git Concepts and Daily Workflows. License Happy Git and GitHub for the useR by Jennifer Bryan is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License.

A Randy’s Notes on this page

A Randy’s Notes on this page Downloading and understanding BpS descriptions going over a BpS document is a great way to not only help people understand BpS, but also to introduce spatial datasets: BpS EVT though s-class rule table (where we get lifeform) EVC and EVH-rule table S-class–look at succession class descriptions to understand what “A” means in an addtional way (in addtion to s-class table) demo downloading BpS descriptions describe key features/sections of document link to Blankenship et al 2021

the-four-ways-to-download-landfire-spatial-data.html
C The four ways to download LANDFIRE Spatial Data

C The four ways to download LANDFIRE Spatial Data LANDFIRE provides three ways to download spatial data: Using the LANDFIRE Map Viewer Downloading CONUS, Hawaii, Alaska or insular area-wide data Streaming the data with a webservice Additionally, Mark Buckner has created the rlandfire package, which allows for direct downloading of LANDFIRE data into an R environment. For this tutorial we will use option 1, downloading data via the LANDFIRE Map Viewer (LMV).
